title: The Death of Nadab and Abihu
shortSummary: Leviticus 10 recounts the tragic incident where Aaron’s sons, Nadab and Abihu, offer unauthorized fire before the LORD and are consumed by divine fire as a result. The chapter emphasizes the holiness of God, the importance of obedience in worship, and the proper conduct required of the priests.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Tabernacle Period during the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Nadab
keyCharacters.description: Son of Aaron and priest who, along with his brother Abihu, offered unauthorized fire before the LORD and was consumed by divine judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Abihu
keyCharacters.description: Son of Aaron and priest who participated with Nadab in offering strange fire and was likewise consumed by the LORD's fire.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest and father of Nadab and Abihu, who mourns their death and receives instructions from Moses and the LORD.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: Leader of Israel who enforces God’s commands, instructs the priests on proper conduct, and oversees the handling of Nadab and Abihu’s bodies.

keyCharacters.name: Eleazar and Ithamar
keyCharacters.description: Aaron’s surviving sons who are instructed on priestly duties and proper handling of offerings following their brothers’ deaths.

definitions.definition: Unauthorized or improper fire offered in worship, not commanded by God, symbolizing disobedience and irreverence.
A vessel used to burn incense during worship, symbolizing prayers ascending to God.
Set apart as holy; dedicated to God’s service and separated from common use.
Holy oil used to consecrate priests and sacred objects, symbolizing God’s presence and blessing.
A sacrifice made to atone for unintentional sins, restoring the relationship between God and His people.

outline.heading: The Unauthorized Offering and Divine Judgment
outline.description: Nadab and Abihu offer unauthorized fire before the LORD, resulting in immediate divine judgment by fire that consumes them, demonstrating God's holiness and intolerance of disobedience.

outline.heading: Moses’ Explanation and the Removal of the Bodies
outline.description: Moses explains that God will be sanctified and glorified before the people, then orders the removal of Nadab and Abihu’s bodies from the sanctuary to maintain holiness.

outline.heading: Instructions to Aaron and His Remaining Sons
outline.description: Moses commands Aaron, Eleazar, and Ithamar not to mourn publicly or leave the tabernacle entrance, emphasizing the sacredness of their office and the anointing oil upon them.

outline.heading: God’s Command Regarding Sobriety in the Tabernacle
outline.description: The LORD commands that Aaron and his sons abstain from wine and strong drink when ministering in the tabernacle to maintain discernment between holy and unholy.

outline.heading: Instructions on Eating the Offerings
outline.description: Moses instructs Aaron and his sons on the proper consumption of the remaining offerings, highlighting the holiness and due portions of the priests.

outline.heading: Moses’ Rebuke and Aaron’s Response
outline.description: Moses rebukes Eleazar and Ithamar for not eating the sin offering in the holy place, but Aaron defends his hesitation due to the recent tragedy; Moses accepts his explanation.

application: Respect and reverence for God’s holiness must govern all aspects of worship and service; unauthorized or careless actions have serious consequences.
Christian leaders and believers alike should maintain sobriety and discernment when approaching God’s presence to serve Him faithfully.
Obedience to God’s commands, even in difficult circumstances, is essential for honoring Him and maintaining fellowship.
Trust in God’s justice and mercy when facing trials or loss, as seen in Aaron’s humble acceptance of God’s will.

keyVerses.text: And Nadab and Abihu, the sons of Aaron, took either of them his censer, and put fire therein, and put incense thereon, and offered strange fire before the LORD, which he commanded them not.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces the critical error of Nadab and Abihu, highlighting the importance of following God’s specific commands in worship.

keyVerses.text: Then Moses said unto Aaron, This is it that the LORD spake, saying, I will be sanctified in them that come nigh me, and before all the people I will be glorified. And Aaron held his peace.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s purpose in holiness and glory, and Aaron’s submission to God’s judgment.

keyVerses.text: Do not drink wine nor strong drink, thou, nor thy sons with thee, when ye go into the tabernacle of the congregation, lest ye die: it shall be a statute for ever throughout your generations:
keyVerses.significance: This command underscores the necessity of sobriety and clear-mindedness in serving God.

keyVerses.text: And when Moses heard that, he was content.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows Moses’ acceptance of Aaron’s explanation, illustrating grace and understanding within God’s law.
